matched.actualTitle: Type Confusion/Type Juggling Authentication Bypass via Array Parameter
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the identical authentication bypass vulnerability caused by PHP type juggling in the strcmp() function. The actual finding provides detailed technical explanation: when password parameter is submitted as an array (password[] or password[0]), strcmp() returns NULL instead of a string comparison result, causing authentication to bypass. Both identify the same vulnerable code location and attack vector. The actual finding includes additional proof (PHP warning: 'strcmp() expects parameter 1 to be string, array given') confirming the vulnerability mechanism.

extra.title: Login Form Credentials Exposed in URL via GET Method
extra.assessment: Valid finding - legitimate vulnerability. The login form uses HTTP GET method instead of POST, causing authentication credentials to be transmitted in plaintext URLs, browser history, server logs, and proxy logs. This is a well-documented security issue separate from the type juggling bypass.

extra.title: Authentication Bypass via Empty Password
extra.assessment: Valid finding - new discovery. The authentication system allows bypassing authentication for the admin user by providing an empty password. This is a separate vulnerability from the type juggling issue - the application fails to validate that password field is non-empty before processing authentication.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection Token in Login Form
extra.assessment: Valid finding - new discovery. The login form lacks any CSRF token or request verification mechanism. No nonce or validation to prevent cross-site request forgery attacks. This is a separate vulnerability from the authentication bypass issues.

extra.title: Weak Input Validation - Parameters Accepted Without Sanitization
extra.assessment: Valid finding - new discovery. The application accepts multiple injection payloads (SQL injection characters, null bytes, array notation, special characters) without any validation errors or filtering. Demonstrates poor input validation practices that could enable various injection attacks.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers in HTTP Response
extra.assessment: Valid finding - new discovery. The application fails to include critical HTTP security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security). These missing headers weaken defense-in-depth security posture against clickjacking, MIME-sniffing, XSS, and SSL stripping attacks.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Server Version Exposed in Error Pages and Headers
extra.location: HTTP response headers and error pages
extra.assessment: Valid finding - new discovery. Server reveals sensitive version information (PHP/5.6.40, Apache/2.4.25) through X-Powered-By header, Server header, and error page footers. This information leakage enables attackers to identify known vulnerabilities and tailor targeted exploits for specific versions.

extra.title: No HTTP Method Restrictions - All Methods Accepted on Login Form
extra.assessment: Valid finding - new discovery. The server accepts all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, HEAD, OPTIONS, PATCH) without restriction or 405 responses. Expected behavior is to only allow GET/POST and reject other methods. This enables WAF bypasses, potential cache poisoning, and HTTP method confusion attacks.

extra.title: Insufficient Access Control on Static Resources - .htaccess File Existence Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: Valid finding - new discovery. Apache server returns HTTP 403 Forbidden for .htaccess files instead of 404 Not Found, revealing their existence to attackers. While the files cannot be read, the HTTP status code distinction allows reconnaissance of server configuration.

extra.title: Parameter Case Sensitivity Allows Bypassing Error Handling
extra.assessment: Valid finding - new discovery. The application exhibits unexpected behavior with parameter case sensitivity. Using uppercase parameter names (Username/Password instead of username/password) bypasses error handling and authentication validation logic, causing different responses. This allows evasion of security controls and error logging.
